Platform.Title: Affymetrix RML Custom Pathogenic chip 7
Platform.Description:
NOTE 1: In general, probesets IDs containing .rc and .m are custom probe-designs covering short regions (intergenic, "non-coding") close to a defined open reading frame.
NOTE 2: GPL8069_probe_tab.txt.gz does not contain sequences

Column.Name: ID
Column.Description: identification of probe set

Column.Name: type
Column.Description: control or designed from Sa USA 300

Column.Name: Descriptions
Column.Description: description of probe-set

Column.Name: RANGE_START
Column.Description: bp start position relative to chromosome/plasmid

Column.Name: RANGE_END
Column.Description: bp stop position relative to chromosome/plasmid

Column.Name: RANGE_GB
Column.Description: chromosome ID #

Column.Name: length
Column.Description: length

Column.Name: species
Column.Description: control or designed from Sa USA 300

Column.Name: orientation
Column.Description: orientation of designed probe-set or strand from designed probe-set

Column.Name: SPOT_ID
Column.Description: spot identifier

Sample.Title: media= TSB , time point 0 , replicate 1

Channel.Treatment-Protocol: At chosen time points (0, 30, 60, 90 and 120 min) 10 ml samples were collected. Bacteria were washed with DPBS and plated on TSA for CFU count. Culture samples at all time points were stained with Wright-Giemsa stain and were examined under the microscope
Channel.Growth-Protocol: S. aureus USA300 strain was cultured in tryptic soy broth (TSB; Becton Dickinson) to mid-exponential growth phase (OD600~0.75), washed once with Dulbecco’s PBS (DPBS; Sigma-Aldrich) and added to fresh TSB media, human normal serum and human heparinized blood to a final concentration 107CFU/ml. Blood and serum were obtained from six healthy individuals. Each human subject included in the study gave informed consent. Bacteria were incubated with gentle rotation for up to 120 min at 37°C with 5% CO2. At chosen time points (0, 30, 60, 90 and 120 min) 10 ml samples were collected
Channel.Extract-Protocol: RNA was isolated from collected samples by RNeasy Mini Kit (Qiagen) with addition use of Bacterial-RNA Protect (Qiagen), and contaminating chromosomal DNA was removed by TurboDNase (Ambion/Applied Biosystem). To remove eukaryotic RNA, samples were subjected to MICROBEnrich™ (Ambion) treatment.
Channel.Label: biotin
Channel.Label-Protocol: Fragmented and biotin-dUTP-labeled aRNA was generated from purified staphylococcal RNA followed by manufacturer protocol MessageAmp™ II-Bacteria Kit (Ambion).

Sample.Hybridization-Protocol: Samples were hybridized to the custom Affymetrix GeneChip (RMLchip7, GEO platform GPL8069) containing the USA300 genome at 100% coverage (2560/2560).
Sample.Scan-Protocol: GeneChips were scanned using the Affymetrix GeneChip Scanner 7GPlus.
Sample.Description: Gene expression data from_media= TSB time point 0 replicate 1 3341_NM-1_Sa_01_TSB-0-1-1_01_9836
Sample.Data-Processing: The data were analyzed with GCOS 1.4 using Affymetrix default analysis with a scale filter for Se genes setting and global scaling as normalization method. The trimmed mean target intensity of each array was arbitrarily set to 500.

Column.Name: VALUE
Column.Description: MAS5.0 signal intensity

Column.Name: ABS_CALL
Column.Description: indicating whether the transcript was present (P), absent (A), or marginal (M)

Channel.Treatment-Protocol: At chosen time points (0, 30, 60, 90 and 120 min) 10 ml samples were collected. Bacteria were washed with DPBS and plated on TSA for CFU count. Culture samples at all time points were stained with Wright-Giemsa stain and were examined under the microscope
Channel.Growth-Protocol: S. aureus USA300 strain was cultured in tryptic soy broth (TSB; Becton Dickinson) to mid-exponential growth phase (OD600~0.75), washed once with Dulbecco’s PBS (DPBS; Sigma-Aldrich) and added to fresh TSB media, human normal serum and human heparinized blood to a final concentration 107CFU/ml. Blood and serum were obtained from six healthy individuals. Each human subject included in the study gave informed consent. Bacteria were incubated with gentle rotation for up to 120 min at 37°C with 5% CO2. At chosen time points (0, 30, 60, 90 and 120 min) 10 ml samples were collected
Channel.Extract-Protocol: RNA was isolated from collected samples by RNeasy Mini Kit (Qiagen) with addition use of Bacterial-RNA Protect (Qiagen), and contaminating chromosomal DNA was removed by TurboDNase (Ambion/Applied Biosystem). To remove eukaryotic RNA, samples were subjected to MICROBEnrich™ (Ambion) treatment.
Channel.Label: biotin
Channel.Label-Protocol: Fragmented and biotin-dUTP-labeled aRNA was generated from purified staphylococcal RNA followed by manufacturer protocol MessageAmp™ II-Bacteria Kit (Ambion).

Sample.Hybridization-Protocol: Samples were hybridized to the custom Affymetrix GeneChip (RMLchip7, GEO platform GPL8069) containing the USA300 genome at 100% coverage (2560/2560).
Sample.Scan-Protocol: GeneChips were scanned using the Affymetrix GeneChip Scanner 7GPlus.

Sample.Title: media= Serum , time point 30 , replicate 3

Channel.Treatment-Protocol: At chosen time points (0, 30, 60, 90 and 120 min) 10 ml samples were collected. Bacteria were washed with DPBS and plated on TSA for CFU count. Culture samples at all time points were stained with Wright-Giemsa stain and were examined under the microscope
Channel.Growth-Protocol: S. aureus USA300 strain was cultured in tryptic soy broth (TSB; Becton Dickinson) to mid-exponential growth phase (OD600~0.75), washed once with Dulbecco’s PBS (DPBS; Sigma-Aldrich) and added to fresh TSB media, human normal serum and human heparinized blood to a final concentration 107CFU/ml. Blood and serum were obtained from six healthy individuals. Each human subject included in the study gave informed consent. Bacteria were incubated with gentle rotation for up to 120 min at 37°C with 5% CO2. At chosen time points (0, 30, 60, 90 and 120 min) 10 ml samples were collected
Channel.Extract-Protocol: RNA was isolated from collected samples by RNeasy Mini Kit (Qiagen) with addition use of Bacterial-RNA Protect (Qiagen), and contaminating chromosomal DNA was removed by TurboDNase (Ambion/Applied Biosystem). To remove eukaryotic RNA, samples were subjected to MICROBEnrich™ (Ambion) treatment.

Channel.Treatment-Protocol: At chosen time points (0, 30, 60, 90 and 120 min) 10 ml samples were collected. Bacteria were washed with DPBS and plated on TSA for CFU count. Culture samples at all time points were stained with Wright-Giemsa stain and were examined under the microscope
Channel.Growth-Protocol: S. aureus USA300 strain was cultured in tryptic soy broth (TSB; Becton Dickinson) to mid-exponential growth phase (OD600~0.75), washed once with Dulbecco’s PBS (DPBS; Sigma-Aldrich) and added to fresh TSB media, human normal serum and human heparinized blood to a final concentration 107CFU/ml. Blood and serum were obtained from six healthy individuals. Each human subject included in the study gave informed consent. Bacteria were incubated with gentle rotation for up to 120 min at 37°C with 5% CO2. At chosen time points (0, 30, 60, 90 and 120 min) 10 ml samples were collected
Channel.Extract-Protocol: RNA was isolated from collected samples by RNeasy Mini Kit (Qiagen) with addition use of Bacterial-RNA Protect (Qiagen), and contaminating chromosomal DNA was removed by TurboDNase (Ambion/Applied Biosystem). To remove eukaryotic RNA, samples were subjected to MICROBEnrich™ (Ambion) treatment.
Channel.Label: biotin
Channel.Label-Protocol: Fragmented and biotin-dUTP-labeled aRNA was generated from purified staphylococcal RNA followed by manufacturer protocol MessageAmp™ II-Bacteria Kit (Ambion).

Sample.Hybridization-Protocol: Samples were hybridized to the custom Affymetrix GeneChip (RMLchip7, GEO platform GPL8069) containing the USA300 genome at 100% coverage (2560/2560).
Sample.Scan-Protocol: GeneChips were scanned using the Affymetrix GeneChip Scanner 7GPlus.

Sample.Title: media= Serum , time point 60 , replicate 5

Channel.Treatment-Protocol: At chosen time points (0, 30, 60, 90 and 120 min) 10 ml samples were collected. Bacteria were washed with DPBS and plated on TSA for CFU count. Culture samples at all time points were stained with Wright-Giemsa stain and were examined under the microscope
Channel.Growth-Protocol: S. aureus USA300 strain was cultured in tryptic soy broth (TSB; Becton Dickinson) to mid-exponential growth phase (OD600~0.75), washed once with Dulbecco’s PBS (DPBS; Sigma-Aldrich) and added to fresh TSB media, human normal serum and human heparinized blood to a final concentration 107CFU/ml. Blood and serum were obtained from six healthy individuals. Each human subject included in the study gave informed consent. Bacteria were incubated with gentle rotation for up to 120 min at 37°C with 5% CO2. At chosen time points (0, 30, 60, 90 and 120 min) 10 ml samples were collected
Channel.Extract-Protocol: RNA was isolated from collected samples by RNeasy Mini Kit (Qiagen) with addition use of Bacterial-RNA Protect (Qiagen), and contaminating chromosomal DNA was removed by TurboDNase (Ambion/Applied Biosystem). To remove eukaryotic RNA, samples were subjected to MICROBEnrich™ (Ambion) treatment.

Series.Title: Global changes in Staphylococcus aureus gene expression in human blood provide insight into mechanisms of immune evasion and virulence
Series.Summary: Staphylococcus aureus is a leading cause of bloodstream infections worldwide. In the United States, many of these infections are caused by a strain known as USA300. Although progress has been made, our understanding of the S. aureus molecules that promote bacteremia and survival in human blood is incomplete. To that end, we analyzed the USA300 transcriptome during culture in human blood, human serum, and trypticase soy broth (TSB), a standard laboratory culture media. Notably, genes encoding several cytolytic toxins were up-regulated in human blood over time, and hlgA, hlgB, and hlgC (encoding gamma-hemolysin subunits HlgA, HlgB, and HlgC) were among the most highly up-regulated genes at all time points. Culture supernatants derived from a USA300 isogenic hlgABC-deletion strain (LACΔhlgABC) had significantly reduced capacity to form pores in human neutrophils and ultimately cause neutrophil lysis. Compared with the wild-type USA300 strain (LAC), LACΔhlgABC had modestly reduced ability to cause mortality in a mouse bacteremia model. On the other hand, wild-type and LACΔhlgABC strains caused virtually identical disease in a mouse skin infection model, and bacterial survival and neutrophil lysis after phagocytosis in vitro was similar between these strains. Comparison of the cytolytic capacity of culture supernatants from wild-type and isogenic deletion strains lacking hlgABC, lukS/F-PV (encoding PVL), and/or lukDE revealed significant functional redundancy among two-component leukotoxins in vitro. These findings may explain in part the apparent limited contribution of any single two-component leukotoxin to USA300 immune evasion and virulence.
Series.Overall-Design: S. aureus strain USA300 transcriptome during culture in human blood, human serum, and trypticase soy broth (TSB): time course.
